Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2012 10:04PM seabeal wrote: Deb720 - Could you tell me who your surgeon was in Albu. Dr Lopez my onco in Santa Fe referred me to Susan Seedman but I do not know who the plastic is or will be. Dr Lopez also gave me a name of a plastic, Jeff Morehouse, who he recommended.

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2012 01:49PM seabeal wrote: I'm 62 yrs and would have never believed I'ld be thinking of getting a tatto as this wasn't vogue for proper young ladies when I was a lot younger but before I even had my surgery I decided to heck with it I was going to get one when I finished treatment. After all I lived my life as a "proper young lady" and what has it gotten me. Don't get me wrong I've enjoyed my life and it's been interesting but there are so many doors I never opened much less explored because there was a question of "acceptability". If cancer did nothing else for me it took my morality and rubbed it in my face! Since that day I'm healthier (except for the cancer), happier, my marriage is stronger and I look forward to living my life trying something new everyday. I'm now the proud owner of Harley-Davidson Dyna Low Rider and sometimes I ride without a helmet just for the thrill of feeling the wind (Maybe a little stupid, but the point is that I'm trying to overcome my fears and live my life for the joy of it and not to just get to tomorrow because we don't know how many tomorrows we have whether we have cancer or not) After shopping for tattos the question now is how many, what design and where? I just can't make up my mind!

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2013 07:30PM seabeal wrote: Pattysmiles - I had a double mx a year ago with immediate DIEP flap reconstruction. My PS knew there was a possibility that radiation would be needed for my left breast and left it a little larger to compensate for possible shrinkage. I traveled from Taos NM to San Antonio TX to use this specific PS and before he would accept me as a pt I had to agree to have radiation done in San Antonio using the radiologist he works with because all radiation is not equal. It seems that some like to use a little heavier hand because if a little is good a lot has to be better. Although there were extra expense this was the best decision I have made although I have had some healing issues due to the radiation to the second surgery which involved fine tuning and nipple reconstruction. If there is one thing that I've learn that is consistant in the tx of ca on these boards, it is the inconsistancy in the manner of tx each of us receive. Not to say that one way is better than another but due to continue research, new knowledge, so much to learn and just what a doctor feels comfortable with these inconsistancies will continue. It seems it is up to us to each research, question and go with what we are comfortable with because in the end we are the only ones who live with the outcomes.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2013 05:16PM seabeal wrote: Welcome Ann and good luck with your surgery. These are the friends that you may never physically meet but know each other more intimately then others you've known all your life. Thank God for this safe place and all you wonderful ladies.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2012 11:39AM seabeal wrote: Lynn, I know how you feel. I was told 6 hours ago that my biopsy was positive for cancer but I don't know anymore than that. I never thought I would ever be joining a support group much less this one but although my wonderful supportive daughter lives with me and my husband was at my side when I received the news, I've never felt so alone in my life. I don't want to upset anyone especially my daughter. I was fine until an hour before my doctors appointment then full blown panic began to set in. I was again fine after the doctors appointment until 2 hours ago. Don't know what happen and don't know what is going to happen. I have an appointment with the surgeon next Wednesday so maybe I'll know more but I already know it won't be enough.

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2012 10:26PM seabeal wrote: Tomorrow is the big day. I went to PRMA in San Antonio for a consultation and will have my double mastectomy with DIEP reconstruction in the morning. I'm so far behind on reading all the post here but the past couple of weeks have been a whirl wind of activity. Can't say I'm not more then a little nervous, this is a big surgery (6-8 hours). Tomorrow this time one of the most famliar parts of my body will be gone but so will the monster that has turned my life upside down for the 2 months (to the day). We left Taos on Friday spending the night in Amarillo to celebrate my husband's birthday with our family and friends which gave me an opportunity to see all. Arrived in SA late Sat afternoon and have spent the last two days settling into our temp home (included a shopping trip to San Marcus) I'm not so much afraid of the surgery, though I'm dreading the pain, as I am of the knowledge afterwards whether I will need chemo and/or rads. I know that I'm in good hands and have confidence in my surgeons and have made a promise to do whatever I need to do to decrease the risk of going through this again no matter how uncomfortable or scary it may seem. Nothing can be worse then this limbo I've lived in for the past 2 months. Don't know when I'll be back but be assured I'll be here as soon as physically possible. Everyone stay safe and continue to fight the good fight. Each of your stories have been special providing comfort and inspiration. You are all special, special ladies (and gentlemen) and my prayers are with all of you. Carol
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2013 10:36PM seabeal wrote: Mnmom38, I understand how you feel and don't think you are crazy for wanting the chemo. I am Stage 2b, grade 2 with IDC >5cm, onco score of 18 (this was taken on only one tumor when I had 4 tumors which were not related to one another). I was told by my surgeon that if I was his relative he would strongly advise chemo but Oncologist really blew me off. I'm just too freaking tired to fight anymore.

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2013 12:21AM seabeal wrote: Mnmom38 - I envy you getting out on the skies.  I'm definitely not into cross country but I love down hill. We have some really great snow right now and our daughter and family are coming for spring break. Her husband loves to ski but can't go due to healing issues. I have been going to the wound clinic for past 2 months due to extensive tunneling and undermining plus infection in my radiated breast. We are 1/2 the size we were 2 months ago and don't want to risk pulling anything apart. Anyway enjoy the skiing and think of me out there, I can almost feel the wind in my face!

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2013 12:42PM seabeal wrote: Joan if you ever head this way let me know, would love to meet you and more then happy to have you as a guest. Its so beautiful up here no matter the season. The skiing is top rated, spring is breath taking watching everything coming alive and the rivers rushing from the snow melt. Summer temperatures vary depending where you are at but where I live if it hits 90 it is a heat wave and fall provided spectecular colors. It is definitely one of America's hidden treasures.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 12:12AM seabeal wrote: I to am new having been dx 2/17/12 after a routine mamo. I posted what I know from the biopsy path but still having test done before surgery, lumpectomy, so I'm still waiting for a lot of information. Had my MRI yesterday which I thought was a lot worse than either the mamo or biopsy because I'm so claustrophobic. I still have a brain and body CT sched next Thursday then back to the surgeon to determine surgical plan. The first 48 hours were the worse as it felt like weeks rather than hours. Since then it seems like it has been 1 doctor's appointment after another. When I had to go and get more lab done today I thought I can't do this, this thing is taking over my life but then thought "no" you just do it with a different attitude cause I know this is just the beginning. Tomorrow my DH and I are planning to go skiing for the day as things seem to be moving so fast and I know I probably won't be able to go this season after surgery. I haven't had time to ski last year or so far this year because of starting a new job involving the night shift and started back to school to finish my BSN (I'm an RN for 26 yr with an AD) Going to step back from school this term so I can concentrate on this and not knowing what issues are in store. I've only posted a few things here but I've read until my eyes are ready to pop out. I've learned so much from everyone and still  know so little (I'm an ICU nurse at a small rural hospital, not onc) My family thought my computer activities were what was depressing me but quickly let them know that all I've gotten from reading the threads are encouragement, support, and knowledge that the not knowing is so much more frightening then knowing. I hope to get to know each of you better and hope I don't graduate from stage I.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2012 10:06PM seabeal wrote: Guess I overdid it on the slopes yesterday, my back and hips hurt so bad today I could hardly walk and slept most of the day on the heating pad. What a wuss and I haven't even had surgery yet or started tx, I guess I better toughen up. The sleeping part seems to be what I've been doing a lot of since the dx. I do have my appoint for next Monday with surgeon and results for MRI and CTs should be in so we can sched the date. I'm working Fri and Sat night so I'll be able to sneak a peek at the CT report (know I probably shouldn't but can't stand the waiting!) Farmer: So glad you found a way to walk your dogs. I have to Siberian H, age 3 & 4 yr, who are built to pull, but we have put in a lot of work keeping them under control so I hope there are no issues after my surgery. My oldest one has a sixth sense when it comes to children, the elderly or handicap and he is very emphatic with me, its my youngest who sometimes has the mentality of a Texas cheerleader (I can say that since I'm originally from TX). We do have a special belt you can connect their leashes to which comes in handy when you need help being pulled up the mountain. Eph3_12: I know what you mean (I do that a lot) I swore I would never do that again when I woke up one day and realized how much I missed of my children after working 60+ hours/week. I loved my job but not as much as I loved my kids. It's so easy to get caught up and lose your perspective.

Have to say I'm envious as the ground here is still frozen with more snow today on top of snow. Hopefully spring will be here in 1 to 2 or 3 months. Love the mountains but I do miss the longer growing season.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2012 10:41PM seabeal wrote: I need any information you ladies can offer or experiences regarding implants vs TRAM for reconstruction. Met with the onco for the first time today and he agreed that due to multiple tumor sites with primary 5cm and so far a benign mass in the other breast that BLMX would be a better option vs lumpectomy inregards to reoccurance. Now the big decision (meet with surgeon 4/5 so won't know until then if there will be a choice but want to be prepared) is whether to do implants or TRAM. I had never heard of this procedure until he suggested it but after researching it, it sounds great but would like to know about others experiences both good and bad.

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2013 09:36AM seabeal wrote: I am glad you found us runnermom, heck, I'm glad I found us. I'm also glad you to see you posting. As iatiger stated, there are no wrong places to post. We all need to hear from each other as this is how we work through our emotions, fears and accumulate knowledge. You will find you emotions are like a roller coaster and somedays you can be all over the page. This is a safe place to vent and ask questions. No one knows exactly what you are going through like another survivor. Which reminds me, as someone told me during my first days post dx, you are a cancer survivor, you become one the day you received your dx and everyday is another day we have survived. Don't get to worried waiting for you onco score, it took about 3 months before I got mine. I'm not sure if that's the average wait or not but it seems the doctors aren't as concerned about it as we are. Good luck with your treatment and know that you always have friends here whether you are just gathering information or needing to vent (we all have)

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2013 09:33AM seabeal wrote: I don't know Wren if it makes a different how much or how little you know when it comes to plumbing. It seems to be one of those chores that even as you think of it something else will go wrong. Maybe because it so resembles this disease and it's treatment, its my least favorite chore!
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 10:04PM seabeal wrote: I think we are all sorry to be here and wish it wasn't necessary to have a site such as this but thank God it's here and hope you each know how grateful all of us newbies are for the support. I went skiing with DH today and it was the first day since I have gotten my dx that I went hours without it once sticking it's nose in my face. I just enjoyed the sun, snow and wind in my face as I flew down that mountain and kept thinking why haven't I taken the time to do this in the past 1 1/2 years, thats why we moved up here in 2004. I'm from Amarillo TX but my soul has always belonged in the mountains since I can remember and this is my dream come true. We were suppose to be retiring up here but with the economy and now with the future medical expense I don't see that happening for a while if ever but it shouldn't stop us from enjoying our lifes. It seems like once again I got caught up in just existing to live instead of living to love. This has been a wake up call that though the bills need to be paid life needs to be enjoyed NOW cause no one knows how many tomorrows they have. I'm not letting this whip me and as I heard one of you say, I want to throw everything there is at it including the kitchen sink! Anyway I have two full days with no doctor appointments except to get my Siberian Husky to the vet. Hate that I have to take her but sure glad this appointment isn't for me! Hope I can hit the slopes at least one more time before surgery but if not I'll have to work extra hard to be there next season on opening day (if the snow is any good).

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 10:37PM seabeal wrote: OMG! Chocolate! Now this may be the worse news I've received so far. I'll eat anything that has chocolate involved with it. Please don't tell me diet coke is on the list to. - Carol

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2012 08:58PM seabeal wrote: I want to thank everyone for the prayers and to let you know that I was released from the hospital this afternoon. This, without a doubt, was the hardest surgery I've been through but in spite of the edema and pain I know that it will be well worth the effort. Dr Chrysopoulo from PRMA was my surgeon and you are right Sherry, they are all spectacular and do amazing work. Still have a few more hurdles to get through involving the pathology report but after this I think I can face anything at this point. We are going to stay here for a few weeks then travel the 15 hours back home but broken down into 3 stages. Hopefully the pain will have improved by then. Of course if radiation is put on the menu this change some of our plans but will cross that bridge when we get to it. Happy Birthday Truebff! Hope it was a really great one for you. I use to think those days weren't any big deal and just another pie in the face for getting another year older but this experience has really changed my perspective about getting another year older. Thank you again one and all!!!!
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 09:09PM seabeal wrote: Renee congrats on your new job. I never thought I would see the day us nurses wouldn't be able to find 2 jobs on every street corner but it seems that time has arrived in spite of the nursing shortage that's still out there. That worries me some since Taos is so small there is only one street corner in the town. Sherry, we may be passing ships in the night in the morning. I have to call in the morning to go in for a quick check. I have developed a hot red rash under my arms spreading over my back. Skin in stiff, itchy and tender to touch. It sort of looks like cellulitis but then I'm no doctors and have been out of relm since all this has started. The edema has increased considerably since I was discharged yesterday. Anyway I've sent a prayer up for both of us to have good results tomorrow (and everyday) Carol
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2012 11:13PM seabeal wrote: Sherry, hope your appointment went well. I passed today as the rash though still present was much improved this morning. I'll be calling tomorrow to see if the path report is in see if I can pick up another bra to wear while cleaning this one. It was a much better day today, got out and about some to save my sanity. Went to see a show (The Lucky One - really really good) and had dinner out. I'll find out in the morning if I over did things but even if I did it was worth it. If I hadn't gotten out I probably would have just sit around this apartment and cried a lot (been doing a lot of that). I can tell my brain is beginning to clear some of the drugs out as I'm beginning to remember some of the things I can't find because I can't remember where I put them (I know ya'll understand that statement) Here's for another day closer to normality unless somethings else happens before then.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2012 01:03PM seabeal wrote: I agree Junif. I have (had) very dense breast and never felt anything on exam. My routine found a small change, less then 1cm, followed up with US and biopsy showing a slightly larger area then an MRI which found 4 more totaling more the 5cm. A 5th and the largest was found during surgery (I guess no matter what they find or what they tell you, you just never know!). None of the test are infaliable, it's all a crap shoot but I would need to go with the one that turned up the most information (short of exploratory surgery).

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2013 12:17AM seabeal wrote: Had my first back injection this morning. The first 8 hours was great with no pain at all (a glimpse of what is possible). After 8 hours the pain came back full force. I know that the shots aren't permanent but if they work they could buy me a little time. If they don't work this may all be a waste of time. Between constant backpain, healing issues with breast reconstruction, and the wonder pill that sucks estrogen dry its no wonder by moods are all over the place like a pin ball machine.

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2013 01:44PM seabeal wrote: I'm so sorry for your set back. It is depressing and discouraging. I've had wound healing issues in my radiated breast after my second reconstruction (DIEP flap) and have been on antibiotics for 8 weeks and wound clinic 3x week since the first of January. It is starting to heal but still has a ways to go. Since my CA DX my acute back pain has turned to chronic related to degenerative disc disease. I had steroid injection in spine 11  days ago and still have had no relief if anything it is worse cause pain meds aren't helping much. I honestly can see why some people would want to commit suicide due to chronic pain and disease but. . . .

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2012 11:01PM seabeal wrote: I made it through my 12 hour night shift Fri and Sat and slept for a few hours when I got home today so hopefully I'll be able to sleep tonight and be fresh for my appointment with the surgeon in the morning. I know I have to have at least a lumpectomy but will also be going over the results of MRI and CTs and setting a date to get this show on the road. I was able to access my CTs at work since thats where I had them and they all looked good except for 2 - 3cm nodules on my R lung. May be nothing but it worries me as I was a heavy smoker for 36 years although I quit 10 years ago. Amazingly my chest Xray showed good clear lungs overall. Haven't seen the MRI results but never heard back from them so I'll accept that as a good sign. Wish me luck tomorrow. Although I'm more then ready to get this over I'm afraid its going to be a long night, I've cleaned the house from top to bottom since I got up this afternoon.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2012 10:29PM seabeal wrote: Annettek - Thanks. I may you up on that. After the snow goes then we have to wait for the mud to dry except for last spring which was so dry with a drier summer but I don't need to tell you Texans that. We are originally from Amarillo with kids and grandkids living there and DH worked in Austin after the fire working insurance claims. So sorry for all the destruction this horrible drought is bringing my fellow Texans. Deb720 - We're almost neighbors, I live between Taos and Angel Fire. Didn't get that much snow just some small flurries and a whole lot of wind. Small flurries and lots of wind leads to big drifts as you know. Went to Santa Fe today to meet with onco and it was cold this morning but warmed up with plenty of sunshine between here and there except at my house. Judy67 - Let me know if you ever need to visit, we have plenty of beds. I love New Mexico and agree it is beautiful here. I love Texas to, just hated Amarillo (not the people just the town)
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2012 09:52PM seabeal wrote: Li Momma - So sorry to have to welcome you to the group but you couldn't have come to a better place, these ladies are great and can give you so much information. Be persistent both here and with your doctors, knowledge is your greatest weapon. I started this merry-go-round 2/17 when I got the news after a routine mammo and it is a crazy merry-go-round. I've been an RN for 26 years and you would think I would know something but when its in your own backyard you have just as many questions and realize just how much you don't know. Vickie is right about the worst part is waiting for the medical people to point you in the next direction. From the date to dx to the date of surgery was only 2 months but felt like 2 years with so many test, CTs, MRIs, scans, labs and exams that if a stranger came up to me today and asked to see my breast I'ld probably open my shirt without giving it a second thought. Don't do anything until you have all the information you need and want from as many places and physicians you need to visit with. This is an excellent place to start as these ladies "know" the questions to ask which I felt so dumb I didn't even know what to ask first. Make sure your web sites are reputable which this one is and read, read and read some more. I have just started my journey of recovery having had a DMX with Diep flap reconstruction in San Antonio (I live in Taos, NM) on 4/17 but with the knowledge I gain from the questions I asked I feel very comfortable with the decisions I've made so far and with many more to make in the future. Hang in there and ask all the questions you feel the need to ask. Although I'm a real newbie myself, I will help you in anyway that I can. Don't be afraid to ask for support from both family and friends including the ones here. Being afraid, angry, depressed or what ever holding hands with those who care is far better than being alone in the dark. I know because it is very difficult for me to reach out when in need.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2013 12:25PM seabeal wrote: Feb 17 - 1 year ago I heard the words "you have cancer" First year down and what a year it has been. I'm happy I'm alive but feel like I'm falling apart. Next Tues I go to the Spine and Pain Clinic and hopefully will find some relief. I'm tired 23/7 (the first hour of the morning I feel pretty good), still fighting a healing issue regarding my radiated breast going to the wound clinic 3x week (after 2 months its starting to make some progress), AL are making my skin look like crepe paper and feel like I'm aging 2 days for every 1. It doesn't sound like I'm very happy but I am. Cancer has turned my world up side down and I will never be able to think of the future in the same way. Every ache and pain ends with the question "is it cancer?". Before this I never thought I would die of cancer or deal with it, always thought I would go in my sleep or sking down the side of a mountain. Believe it or not I've come a long ways this year and hope I make as much progress next year.

Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: seabeal wrote: I've never joined in internet forums, blogs, or chatrooms because I've never felt comfortable with them but fortunately I ran across this site just a few hours after receiving the dx that I have breast cancer. It was like no big deal until about 5 hours ago (I got the news at noon) and since then I've been sitting here having heart palpatations, increasing headpain, and going from cold sweats to feeling like my skin is going to burn off of my bones. I don't really know anything right now, just that its breast cancer as reported by my primary physician and that I'm lucky that they caught it early. I have an appointment to see the surgeon for a lumpectomy next week and I can't wait to have this thing removed. I feel like I have something disgusting in my body and I just want it out. I wanted to slug my husband when I heard him tell one of our kids that I had a "trace" of cancer. Is that like being a little bit pregnant? And a few minutes ago he asked me if I was "alright" with this. All I could say was that I was fine. I'm just so mad at him and my physician. I feel like I've been lied to cause I know now that they really don't know anything except that its cancer (the biopsy was done 2 days ago.) I'm probably over reacting but I've only had 9 hours to digest all of this. Dx 2/17/2012, IDC Dx 2/17/2012, ILC, 5cm, Stage IIB, Grade 2, 0/9 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 4/17/2012 Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left; Prophylactic mastectomy: Right; Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap Radiation Therapy 5/29/2012 Breast Hormonal Therapy 7/18/2012 Aromasin (exemestane) Surgery 11/6/2012 Reconstruction (left): Nipple reconstruction; Reconstruction (right): Nipple reconstruction Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: What's next? seabeal sandik

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2012 05:56PM seabeal wrote: I am so glad to hear from you and so sorry at the same time. It's been 48 hours since I heard the verdict and it feels like a week. Not much sleep Friday night or Sat but I couldn't drag myself out of bed until 1:30 this afternoon. Like you I've been blaming myself thinking of all the not so wise choices I made in life. I was on replacement hormones for 15 years after my hysterectomy and quit smoking 12 years ago. Although I have Type II diabetes I have got it under control and got my weight back down also. To tell you the truth I've never felt sick and thought I was in pretty good shape for 62 years. I love to ski and hike and had trained for the Susan Komen walk last November but missed it because we weren't able to raise enough money for all of us to go (We live in a small town in Northern NM, sorry I missed the walk but happy we were able to raise as much money as we did). Like you I just want this out and move on or at least know what the next step is. I've never been a patient person, once I make a decision I wanted to get on it yesterday so this is like water torture for me. I've been an RN for 26 years and had started back to school to finish my BSN, guess I'll place that on hold until I know whats going on. I have 1 more week to complete this semester so I'll finish this one up but I'm a bit driven regarding grades and probably don't need the additional stress (not dealing with the cancer but what if I didn't get an "A" !) I'm just going to put it on hold, not giving up. I'm sorry I'm so wordy but I haven't felt like I could really talk to anyone about this as my husband is dealing with this through denial right now and I'm trying to respect what he is going through as well. I think it's so cool that you are a photographer. I love taking pictures and have the cameras and photos to prove it but I'm just an amateur. I love anything dealing with creating and have dabbled in painting, spinning, weaving and knitting. Maybe I'll have the time now to play with my hobbies a little more.  Please keep me posted. I feel like we're sisters now and so grateful for all the sisters that are here but wish none of us were.
Posts.Title: What's next? seabeal sandik
